q1.value: Intentionality, speaker’s attitude and the processing of verbal irony

q2.value: Camilo Rodriguez Ronderos, Ira Andrew Noveck, John Michael Tomlinson Jr

q3.value:
The literature on irony processing has often looked at whether ironic sentences are easier, just as easy, or harder to understand than equivalent literal sentences, resulting in mixed findings. 
In this study, we investigate how information about a speaker's attitude towards an upcoming utterance and expectational biases about the answer to a polar question influence reading times of sentences that are understood either ironically or literally. 
By doing this we wish to investigate whether these two factors can modulate reading times of ironic and literal sentences and help explain why their respective reading speed varies.
The study is thus a 2X2 repeated-measures experiment with the factors Speaker's Attitude (sincere vs. insincere) and expectaitonal bias type (zero bias vs negative bias).
The present experiment is a direct replication of a previous study conducted by the authors: The only change made is the number of participants tested. The current number of participants was determined via simulations using the previous data as the starting point.

q4.value:
We have 3 sets of hypotheses: 

1. answers to comprehension questions: Participants should overall understand a speaker's insincere attitude towards an upcoming sentence as a reliable cue for ironic intent, as indicated by the answer to the comprehension questions in the critical trials. This should translate to an effect of speaker's attitude on the answers to comprehension questions, with answers in the sincere condition being moslty indicative of a literal understanding of the target sentence and answers in the insincere condition showing an ironic understanding of the target sentence. 

2. Reading times: Our main hypothesis is that we should should find a significant interaction between the two factors, such that the insincere-negative bias reading times are shorter than the insincere-zero bias reading times, and the sincere-zero bias reading times are shorter than the sincere-negative bias reading times. This interaction effect should appear in a model using sum-contrast coding.

3. Reading times: Additionally, in a model of the same data using a slider-contrast coding, we make specific predictions regarding the differences between the individual conditions. We predict that:

1. The insincere-zero bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the insincere-negative bias
2. The sincere-negative bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the sincere-zero bias condition
3. The reading times in the insincere-negative bias condition will not be significantly different than the reading times in the sincere-zero bias condition
4. The sincere-zero bias will show significantly shorter reading times than the insincere-zero bias condition
5. the insincere-negative bias condition will show significantly shorter reading times than the sincere-negative bias condition

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The experiment has a repeated measures, latin-square 2X2 design (every participants sees every item but only in one condition and every participant sees every condition at least once) with the factors Expectation Bias (zero vs. negative expectation bias) and Speaker’s Attitude (sincere vs. insincere attitude). There are 4 experimental lists that participants can be assigned to.

q9.value: The order of presentation of critical and filler sentences is randomized for every participant. The assignment of participants to indivual lists is randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited online through the website Prolific and will be tested using the Ibex experimental platform. Participants will be American or Canadian monolingual speakers of English between the ages of 18-35. They will all be right-handed. They will receive 0.85 pounds Sterling for their participation. Participants who answer less than 75% of filler comprehension questions correctly will be excluded from the analysis. 
The reading time data will be log-transformed. Individual observations will be removed from the analysis if they are more than 3 standard deviations away from the condition mean.

q13.value: 220 participants will read 9 critical stories and 10 filler stories each.

q14.value: The number was determined via a power analysis through simulation using pre-existing data as a starting point, following the guidelines provided by Green & Macleod(20016) and using the corresponding R package SimR. For the power analysis, we set the minimum Cohen's d effect size of interest at 0.2 and calculated how many participants we would need to achieve 80% power based on this effect size for every one of the comparisons described in the hypotheses section. We settled on 220 participants because with this number all comparisons should reach at least 80% power.

question.value: See the attached pdf file for all critical items in every condition and corresponding comprehension questions.

We will measure reading times of our target utterances. The reading times will be log-transformed prior to analysis, so that log(RTs) will be the dependent variable used.
We will also measure the question-answering behavior of the questions following both the critical items and the filler items. The accuracy of responses to the filler items will be used as an exclusion criterion, whereas answers to the question in the critical conditions will be used to determine comprehension of either a literal or ironic intent of the critical sentences.

The data will be analyzed fitting a mixed-effects logistic regression model for the accuracy data and a mixed-effects linear regression model for the reading times data. Both models will include a 'maximal' random-effects structure (Barr et al.,2013) with random intercepts and slopes by items and by participants. If any of the models fails to converge, the random effects structure will be reduced in the following order:
1. Remove random correlation of random effects by subjects and then by items
2.Remove random intercepts by subjects and then by items

The model for the reading times will be fitted twice with two different contrast coding schemes. The first one will use a sum-contrast coding scheme (testing main effects and interactions) and the second one a slider-contrast coding scheme (testing simple effects, or differences between individual conditions).

q20.value: The reading times will be log-transformed, following the procedure used for analyzing the data of the previous identical experiment, in order to help normalize the residuals of the regression model.

q21.value: Statistical inference will follow the model of null-hypothesis significance testing, with an alpha level set at 0.05: P-values below this threshold will be taken as evidence against the null-hypothesis. Additionally, we will consider statistical significance in relation to the size of specific effects: We expect the predicted effects to have a cohen's d value of at least 0.2.

q22.value:
Data will be excluded in 3 ways:

1. Participants who answer less than 75% of the filler comprehension questions accurately will be excluded from the analysis.
2. log-transformed reading times more than 3 standard deviations away from the condition mean will be excluded. 
3. If a participant answered a critical comprehension question incorrectly (i.e. understood the sentence literally in the insincere condtions or ironically in the sincere conditions), the reading times from this trial will be excluded from the analysis.

registration_responses.q2: Camilo Rodriguez Ronderos, Ira Andrew Noveck, John Michael Tomlinson Jr

This interaction effect should appear in a model using sum-contrast coding.

1. The insincere-zero bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the insincere-negative bias
2. The sincere-negative bias condition will show significantly longer reading times than the sincere-zero bias condition
3. The reading times in the insincere-negative bias condition will not be significantly different than the reading times in the sincere-zero bias condition
4. The sincere-zero bias will show significantly shorter reading times than the insincere-zero bias condition
5. the insincere-negative bias condition will show significantly shorter reading times than the sincere-negative bias condition

attributes.title: Investigation on origin and genetic diversity of Wild Boars in Northeast Asia via Mitochondrial D-loop markers

q1.value: Investigation on origin and genetic diversity of Wild Boars in Northeast Asia via Mitochondrial D-loop markers

q4.value: I have no hypotheses about our research, this is a tentative work.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We determined the mtDNA D-loop sequence of 23 wild boars from northeast Asia and analyzed the sequence of 480 Eurasian wild boars from NCBI.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: I will gain the data by sequencing the region in the subjects' genome that we interested in and the rest part of data I will collect from the NCBI database.

q13.value: We need at least 20 animal individuals for the sampling and at least 450 existing data from the database.

question.value: There could be inconsistency while analyzing and aligning the sequences of subjects that from the same area or different areas.
I will use the software (spss) to do the statistical work with our data and analyzing results.

attributes.title: Trust in expertise, partisanship and ideology identity

q1.value: Trust in expertise, political partisanship, and ideological identity

q2.value: Gabriela Jiga-Boy, Dion Curry, Louis Bromfield, Leaf Van Boven

q3.value:
A ‘party-over-policy’ effect explains why Democrats (vs. Republicans) support a climate change policy more if put forward by Democratic (vs. Republican) legislators (Van Boven, Ehret & Sherman, 2018). But how does this extend to trust? Do citizens trust experts regardless of political ideology or is expertise inherently partisan? We investigate partisanship effects on types of trust (healthy trust, excessive trust, mistrust, and distrust, as well as trust in impact vs. production science), and components of trust (competence, integrity, benevolence, and quality of science).

RESEARCH QUESTION 1: Does political partisanship shape individuals’ trust in expertise and the legitimacy of experts’ contribution to the political process?

RESEARCH QUESTION 2: How are different types of trust and how are different components of trust affected by political partisanship, ideological identity, and source partisanship?

q4.value:
RESEARCH QUESTION 1: 

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on policy support: Participants will support a policy more if it is proposed by the side matching their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than by the side with the opposing partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts is Remain voter). This will be referred to as ‘partisanship-over-policy effect’. 

H1a-c (non-directional): Political ideology, actual knowledge, and perceived knowledge will moderate the effect of source partisanship x participant partisanship on policy support.

H2 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on trust in expertise: Participants will trust expertise more if it pertains to experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) and will be more willing to trust the use of this evidence in policy-making. Conversely, participants will trust expertise less if it pertains to experts on the opposite side of their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter), and will be less willing to trust the use of this evidence in policy-making.

H3 (directional): Perceived similarity with the source will moderate the effect of source partisanship x participant partisanship on trust in expertise.

H4 (directional): Trust will partially mediate the ‘partisanship-over-policy effect’. 

H5 (non-directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on legitimacy of expertise: We predict an interaction effect on legitimacy of expertise (i.e. on whether experts should contribute to the political process as input, throughput or output). 

H6 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on behavioural measure: Participants will be more willing to write a letter to their local MP supporting/opposing the policy if the policy was proposed by the side matching their partisan allegiance (EU if Remain voter, UK if Leave voter) than by the side with the opposing partisan allegiance (EU if Leave voter, UK is Remain voter). 

RESEARCH QUESTION 2:

2.1 
TYPES OF TRUST: Healthy trust (= healthy vulnerability to positive motivations and past experiences of other actors - e.g., ‘trust in family, that is based on past experience); Excessive trust (= not applying proper levels of skepticism to information coming from their own party); Mistrust (= vigilance, healthy skepticism, or a ‘cautious attitude that propels citizens to maintain a watchful eye on the political and social happenings within their communities”, Lenard, 2008); Distrust (= heuristic cynicism).

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on rankings of types of trust: Participants will rank Distrust and Excessive Trust as more representative of them and Healthy Trust and Mistrust as less representative of them if it pertains to experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than if it pertains to experts on the opposite side of their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).

H2 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on types of trust: Participants will display more Excessive Trust in expertise, more Distrust in expertise, but not more Healthy Trust or Mistrust in expertise if it concerns experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than if it concerns experts who don’t (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).  

2.2 
TYPES OF TRUST: Trust in impact vs. production science 
H1 (directional): Participant ideology will influence trust in impact vs. production science (McCright, Dentzman, Charters & Dietz, 2013): Liberals will trust impact science more and conservatives will trust production science more. 

H2 (directional): Participant’s partisanship will influence trust in impact vs. production science: Remain voters will trust impact science more than Leave voters; the latter will trust production science more than the former.

H3 (non-directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship will influence participants’ trust in impact vs. production science. 

2.3 
COMPONENTS OF TRUST (adapted from Hendriks, Kienhues & Bromme, 2015; Hamm, Smidt & Mayer, 2019): Competence, integrity, benevolence, quality of science.

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on components of trust: Participants who judge a policy advised by experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) will judge the experts at the source of the policy as having more benevolence, more integrity, and performing a better-quality science, but not as more competent, than participants who judge a policy advised by experts who do not share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We have a 2 x 3 between-subjects design with 2 factors (source partisanship by participant partisanship): 
•	Factor 1: Source partisanship of hypothetical policy regarding food safety (UK food safety experts vs. EU food safety experts vs. no source mentioned = control) 
•	Factor 2: Participant partisanship (whether participants voted for the UK to Leave the EU vs. Remain in the EU at the 2016 EU referendum).

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the six equally sized, predetermined blocks. The random assignment function will be embedded in the Survey Flow on Qualtrics. (see here for instructions: https://www.qualtrics.com/community/discussion/1658/block-randomisation).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the platform Prolific Academic (https://www.prolific.co/). Prolific provides a pool of participants to whom the study will be advertised. To take part, participants will need to be: British citizens, living in the UK at present, of or older than 21 years of age. They will have to have voted in the 2016 EU referendum, and to not have participated in another study the main investigators involved in this project have conducted in the last 2 years, also on Prolific Academic. Fifty percent of the sample will consist of voters who voted for the UK to Leave the EU, while the remaining 50% of the sample will consist of voters who voted for the UK to Remain in the EU. We only aim to target participants who can complete the experiment on a tablet, laptop, or a desktop computer, not a mobile phone. These inclusion criteria will be entered as pre-screening criteria on Prolific. Participants will be paid at a rate of £7.50/hour, or £2.00 per participant, expecting the study to take, on average, 16 minutes (which was confirmed by the pilot data, n = 39). The total cost of the data collection will be £2,448. We plan to finalize data collection before January 31, 2020.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 900 participants for the main study, based on Ehret et al (2018) and on our funding (funding for this data collection was secured by Dr Dion Curry).

q14.value: We aim to recruit 900 participants (450 Remain and 450 Leave voters in the 2016 EU referendum, yielding 150/condition), based on Ehret, Van Boven & Sherman (2018)’s replication study, which was itself based on the 3-way interaction in the main study.

question.value:
Factor 1: Source partisanship of hypothetical policy regarding food safety (UK food safety experts vs. EU food safety experts vs. no source mentioned = control). Please see attached document including the text for this manipulation. 

Factor 2: Participant partisanship (whether participants voted for the UK to Leave the EU vs. Remain in the EU at the 2016 EU referendum). This factor will be manipulated by pre-screening participants on Prolific prior to starting data collection. We will thus have a pool of participants who voted Leave and a pool of participants who voted Remain, to which we will distribute the survey.
Please see the document already attached, titled 'OSF_Materials'. It includes all variables measured in this study.
Please see the document attached titled 'OSF_Index'. The index rules are inputted in blue.
Please see the document attached, titled 'OSF_AnalysesPlan'.

q20.value: We plan to center all data to the mean, prior to conducting any regression analyses. More information is provided in 'OSF_AnalysesPlan' and in 'OSF_Index'.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria, as well as confidence intervals and effect size estimates for determining if the multiple regression results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
We plan to perform and present two statistical analyses: One including all participants, regardless of their answers to the manipulation check items 1-3, and one excluding the participants who gave wrong answers to the manipulation check items 1-3. We do not plan a priori to exclude the latter before conducting statistical analyses because we fear that the manipulation checks might not be the best way to assess the quality of our manipulation (see Hauser, Ellsworth & Gonzalez, 2018; Fayant, Sigall, Lemonnier, Retsin & Alexopoulos, 2017; also Ejelöv & Luke, 2020, JESP; Montgomery, Nyhan & Torres, 2018, American Journal of Political Science) or that excluding them might violate random allocation. Hence, eliminating the data from those participants might be a suboptimal decision and we decided to present analyses with and without participants who failed them.  

We do plan to exclude from any analyses participants who indicated that they understood specific hypotheses of this study at the suspicion probe stage. If, however, participants only provide generic 

Manipulation check items 4 and 5 will test the extent to which all three experimental conditions of the variable ‘source partisanship’ are perceived as equally partisan. If the differences among the conditions are statistically significant, we will take that information into account when interpreting the finding pertaining to this variable.

q23.value: If a participant does not complete the measures of interest to test the main study hypotheses (i.e. trust measures and policy support measures), they will not be included in the analyses.

q24.value:
•	(Directional) Trust in other voters (average Remain vs. average Leave voter) will partially mediate the ‘partisanship-over-policy effect’. 
•	(Directional) Participants’ ideology and partisanship will influence their trust in politicians: Participants to the left of the ideology spectrum and Remain voters will display more healthy trust and more mistrust than participants to the right of the ideology spectrum and Leave voters; the former will also display less excessive trust and less distrust than the latter.  
•	‘How participants feel about Brexit’ might moderate the main findings. 
•	Any other analyses performed will be included in the exploratory section and will be interpreted as such.

registration_responses.q1: Trust in expertise, political partisanship, and ideological identity
registration_responses.q2: Gabriela Jiga-Boy, Dion Curry, Louis Bromfield, Leaf Van Boven
registration_responses.q3:
A ‘party-over-policy’ effect explains why Democrats (vs. Republicans) support a climate change policy more if put forward by Democratic (vs. Republican) legislators (Van Boven, Ehret & Sherman, 2018). But how does this extend to trust? Do citizens trust experts regardless of political ideology or is expertise inherently partisan? We investigate partisanship effects on types of trust (healthy trust, excessive trust, mistrust, and distrust, as well as trust in impact vs. production science), and components of trust (competence, integrity, benevolence, and quality of science).

RESEARCH QUESTION 1: Does political partisanship shape individuals’ trust in expertise and the legitimacy of experts’ contribution to the political process?

RESEARCH QUESTION 2: How are different types of trust and how are different components of trust affected by political partisanship, ideological identity, and source partisanship?
registration_responses.q4:
RESEARCH QUESTION 1: 

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on policy support: Participants will support a policy more if it is proposed by the side matching their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than by the side with the opposing partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts is Remain voter). This will be referred to as ‘partisanship-over-policy effect’. 

H1a-c (non-directional): Political ideology, actual knowledge, and perceived knowledge will moderate the effect of source partisanship x participant partisanship on policy support.

H2 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on trust in expertise: Participants will trust expertise more if it pertains to experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) and will be more willing to trust the use of this evidence in policy-making. Conversely, participants will trust expertise less if it pertains to experts on the opposite side of their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter), and will be less willing to trust the use of this evidence in policy-making.

H3 (directional): Perceived similarity with the source will moderate the effect of source partisanship x participant partisanship on trust in expertise.

H4 (directional): Trust will partially mediate the ‘partisanship-over-policy effect’. 

H5 (non-directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on legitimacy of expertise: We predict an interaction effect on legitimacy of expertise (i.e. on whether experts should contribute to the political process as input, throughput or output). 

H6 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on behavioural measure: Participants will be more willing to write a letter to their local MP supporting/opposing the policy if the policy was proposed by the side matching their partisan allegiance (EU if Remain voter, UK if Leave voter) than by the side with the opposing partisan allegiance (EU if Leave voter, UK is Remain voter). 

RESEARCH QUESTION 2:

2.1 
TYPES OF TRUST: Healthy trust (= healthy vulnerability to positive motivations and past experiences of other actors - e.g., ‘trust in family, that is based on past experience); Excessive trust (= not applying proper levels of skepticism to information coming from their own party); Mistrust (= vigilance, healthy skepticism, or a ‘cautious attitude that propels citizens to maintain a watchful eye on the political and social happenings within their communities”, Lenard, 2008); Distrust (= heuristic cynicism).

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on rankings of types of trust: Participants will rank Distrust and Excessive Trust as more representative of them and Healthy Trust and Mistrust as less representative of them if it pertains to experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than if it pertains to experts on the opposite side of their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).

H2 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on types of trust: Participants will display more Excessive Trust in expertise, more Distrust in expertise, but not more Healthy Trust or Mistrust in expertise if it concerns experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) than if it concerns experts who don’t (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).  

2.2 
TYPES OF TRUST: Trust in impact vs. production science 
H1 (directional): Participant ideology will influence trust in impact vs. production science (McCright, Dentzman, Charters & Dietz, 2013): Liberals will trust impact science more and conservatives will trust production science more. 

H2 (directional): Participant’s partisanship will influence trust in impact vs. production science: Remain voters will trust impact science more than Leave voters; the latter will trust production science more than the former.

H3 (non-directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship will influence participants’ trust in impact vs. production science. 

2.3 
COMPONENTS OF TRUST (adapted from Hendriks, Kienhues & Bromme, 2015; Hamm, Smidt & Mayer, 2019): Competence, integrity, benevolence, quality of science.

H1 (directional): Source partisanship x participant partisanship effect on components of trust: Participants who judge a policy advised by experts who share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Remain voter, UK experts if Leave voter) will judge the experts at the source of the policy as having more benevolence, more integrity, and performing a better-quality science, but not as more competent, than participants who judge a policy advised by experts who do not share their partisan allegiance (EU experts if Leave voter, UK experts if Remain voter).

attributes.title: Fragmentation effects on North American mammal species systematic review and meta-analysis

summary.value: This registration outlines the process by which we will conduct our systematic review. At the time of registration, the review had not begun. This registration also includes a coding worksheet that outlines how we will score the various studies included in our review, and a ROSES for systematic review protocol.

registration_responses.summary: This registration outlines the process by which we will conduct our systematic review. At the time of registration, the review had not begun. This registration also includes a coding worksheet that outlines how we will score the various studies included in our review, and a ROSES for systematic review protocol.

attributes.title: Effect of weighted blankets vs. ordinary blankets on hormone secretion, sleep and memory consolidation.

q1.value: Effect of weighted blankets vs. ordinary blankets on hormone secretion, sleep and memory consolidation.

q2.value: Swathy Karamchedu, Lieve von Egmond, Filip Andersson, Jonathan Cedernaes, Kerstin Uvnas-Moberg, Christian Benedict

q3.value:
Tactile stimulation such as massage, stroking and even hugging an inanimate communication medium (non-living stimuli) releases oxytocin which in turn decreases ACTH and cortisol levels, and increases serotonin and dopamine levels by attenuating sympathetic and increasing parasympathetic activity via the autonomic nervous system. These stress reducing effects are induced through pressure and temperature receptors in the skin.
Weighted blankets have been suggested as interventions that could provide the necessary tactile stimulation to decrease stress and improve sleep. However, there have been mixed results regarding their effects on objectively measured sleep in patients with autism spectrum disorder and insomnia, although participants in these studies subjectively preferred them over the ordinary alternatives. There has also been no research so far examining the effect of weighted blankets on heart rate variability (which can be used as an indicator of stress, or the release of hormones such as cortisol and oxytocin.

q4.value: In the present study, we aim to look at the effect of weighted blankets versus ordinary blankets on measures of sleep (e.g. number of nocturnal awakenings; total sleep duration), heart rate variability, endocrine response (hormone levels), salivary alpha amylase (enzyme used to measure of sympathetic activity), and memory consolidation. We will also compare the effects of weighted blankets vs. ordinary blankets on sleep parameters in the adaption nights (between-subject design).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a within-subject, counterbalanced design, with each subject undergoing both experimental conditions (sleep with weighted blanket and ordinary blanket), +3 days apart from each other. Prior to the experimental visits, participants will also undergo two adaptation nights, each with one of the blankets. Each adaptation night will precede the day before each experimental night. Within subject factors include blanket and session. The study protocol has been approved by the Regional Ethical Committee, Lund, Sweden (Dnr 2019-04541).

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions in their first visit using a computer generated random sequence (https://www.randomizer.org/)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the general population through online/poster advertisements placed in bus-stops and other such locations and on relevant websites. They will be screened for eligibility through online questionnaires. Participants should be healthy adults above 18 years of age with no history of physical or psychological health/sleep related issues, with normal BMI and sleep onset habits (2200-2400 hrs). Only female participants on hormonal contraceptives (with estrogen and progesterone) will be recruited to mitigate effects of the menstrual cycle on the measured outcomes.
We will use saliva samples for oxytocin and cortisol measurements, an oura ring (https://ouraring.com/) for heart rate variability and sleep onset latency and sleep quality measurement, blood samples for biomarkers of appetite and brain health, 2d object location for declarative memory and a finger-sequence tapping task for procedural memory measurement, and finally visual analogue scales for subjective measures of stress, sleepiness, anxiety, relaxedness and well-restedness.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 24 male and female participants.

q15.value: We will attempt to recruit up to 32 participants, assuming that not all will complete both the experimental sessions.

question.value:
The primary outcomes measured in the hour prior to sleep include objective measurements of salivary oxytocin/melatonin/cortisol/alpha-amylase levels, sleep onset latency and heart rate variability as well as the subjective/perceived effects of the weighted blanket (such as levels of stress, sleepiness, anxiety and relaxedness) and how the objective and subjective measures may relate.
The secondary outcomes measured will be the objective and subjective measures of sleep quality and memory consolidation (spatial and procedural), as well as cortisol awakening response, blood bio-markers of appetite regulation and brain health, and subjective measures of stress, sleepiness, anxiety and restfulness after awakening.

We will use repeated measures ANOVA (within-subject factors: blanket, time) and post hoc t-tests (or non-parametric tests in case of skewed distributions of the DV) to analyze our results. The independent variable will be blanket type and dependent variables will be saliva oxytocin/melatonin/cortisol, hear rate variability, sleep onset latency, sleep quality, declarative and procedural memory performance, and subjective ratings of stress, sleepiness, anxiety and relaxedness and restfulness. No sex-specific interactions will be tested.
The comparison of the effects of weighted blanket vs. ordinary blanket on sleep parameters (sleep onset latency, wake after sleep onset, sleep efficiency, subjective sleep satisfaction) in the adaption nights is based on a between-subject design (ie., half of the participants will sleep in their first adaption night with a weighted blanket whereas the other half will sleep in their first adaption night with an ordinary blanket ). The effects of weighted blanket vs. ordinary blanket on sleep parameters in the first laboratory adaption night will be analyzed with t-tests (or non-parametric tests in case of skewed distributions of the DV).

attributes.title: Are training interventions effective at improving the clinical skills of therapists in or following professional postgraduate training?

q1.value: Are training interventions effective at improving the clinical skills of therapists in or following professional postgraduate training?

q3.value: Though psychotherapists receive professional training, it is not clear whether evidence strongly supports how this training is done and whether it is effective. Therefore, this is a systematic literature review of the effectiveness of training interventions for psychotherapists who are either in, or have completed, post-graduate training.

q4.value: Psychotherapeutic training improves the clinical skills, competence and knowledge of trainees

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic literature review.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The data exists in the form of completed research studies. Initial scoping searches have been completed to ensure that this is a viable research question and project. The results of these searches have not been investigated further than the reading of the study abstracts. A formal literature search has not yet been conducted.

question.value:
This procedure is an updated version of a protocol published on February 8th 2020. This followed initial searches in which it was identified that Inclusion and exclusion criteria were not adequate to filter out studies not felt relevant to the research question. Additionally, initial scoping searching had missed the update completed by Hill and Knox in 2013, which updated their 2006 review.  The original protocol can be viewed here: osf.io/pzcbq. 

The literature will be searched systematically using the Scopus, Medline and PsychINFO databases. A comprehensive review was completed by Hill and Knox (2013) therefore results will be limited to those published from 2013 onwards. Duplications will be checked and removed.  In contrast to the original protocol publication more comprehensive searches have now been completed therefore the following terms are felt to be appropriate and will be employed in the searches. How these are implemented will also vary between databases given the differences in their functionality. The search terms are: 

training (in title)

AND therapist  OR  psychologist  OR  psychotherapist  OR  "cognitive behavioral therapist"  OR  "cognitive behavioural therapist"  OR  cbt  OR  counselor  OR  counsellor 

AND abilit*  OR  skill  OR  competence 

Include: English language only, studies published from 2013-present

Once this search is complete forward and backwards searches will be completed. Forward searches will be completed by using "As cited by" in google scholar. Backward searches will be completed by looking through reference lists. 

The grey literature will be searched using Google Scholar and dissertations will be searched for using https://ethos.bl.uk/ 

All identified studies will be systemically assessed for inclusion using PRISMA guidelines (Moher, Liberati, Tezlaff, & Altman, 2009). Study selection will be guided by the PICO framework (Schardt, Adams, Owens, Keitz & Fontelo, 2007).
P: Therapists delivering psychotherapy who are either in or have completed postgraduate professional training. 
I: Any intervention which is aimed at improving the clinical skill, knowledge or competence of participants.
C: At minimum studies which have included pre and post measurements. 
O: Outcomes must be assessing clinical skill, knowledge or competence of participants.

Exclusion criteria: 
Studies published before 2013. 
Qualitative studies
Published in a language other than English
Preliminary/ pilot/ feasibility
Studies less than 2 weeks in duration
No face to face component

Inclusion criteria:
Psychotherapists either in or who have completed professional postgraduate training- defined in the paper as therapists

q13.value: As this is a systematic literature sample sizes are not applicable

q15.value: Systematic searches will be conducted today 22.2.20. Search alerts will be set up for the next two weeks. However, analysis and write up will take place after this date, and therefore no further studies will be included after 7.3.20.

question.value: N/A

Variables will not be manipulated. As this is a systematic literature review this is not yet clear and has the possibility to be varied. Outcomes should measure clinical skills, knowledge or competence of psychotherapists.

It is anticipated that the outcome variables will diverge such that meta-analysis techniques cannot be implemented. THerefore the analysis plan for this review is complete a study quality analysis using Down's and Blacks. This will be used to form part of a narrative synthesis of the literature quality and findings.

q25.value: A previous protocol was published on 8.2.20. This protocol updates and refines the protocol following initial searches raising problems with search terms and inclusion and exclusion criteria. This can be reviewed here: osf.io/pzcbq

registration_responses.q1: Are training interventions effective at improving the clinical skills of therapists in or following professional postgraduate training?
registration_responses.q3: Though psychotherapists receive professional training, it is not clear whether evidence strongly supports how this training is done and whether it is effective. Therefore, this is a systematic literature review of the effectiveness of training interventions for psychotherapists who are either in, or have completed, post-graduate training.
registration_responses.q4: Psychotherapeutic training improves the clinical skills, competence and knowledge of trainees
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q11: The data exists in the form of completed research studies. Initial scoping searches have been completed to ensure that this is a viable research question and project. The results of these searches have not been investigated further than the reading of the study abstracts. A formal literature search has not yet been conducted.

registration_responses.q15: Systematic searches will be conducted today 22.2.20. Search alerts will be set up for the next two weeks. However, analysis and write up will take place after this date, and therefore no further studies will be included after 7.3.20.
